attributes.description: Tracing the origins of the components/raw materials of my favorite guitar, a 1999 Paul Reed Smith Custom 22 Soapbar.
attributes.title: Paul Reed Smith Custom 22 Soapbar

attributes.description:
The guitar currently resides at my house in Perkinsville, Vermont. It was born on August 30th, 1999 and assembled by a man with the signature "MSG" and finally checked by a man with the initals "RH".

In its present condition the guitar is worth around 2,000 dollars.
attributes.title: My House

attributes.description: These guys produce the exact kind of Polyester found in the bottom coat of PRS guitar body finishes. Very likely the chemicals they produce are in 100,000s of guitars worldwide.
attributes.address: Dr Homi Bhabha Rd, Pune, Maharashtra, India
attributes.title: National Chemical Laboratory

attributes.description: Brass is an important componet of hardware used in PRS guitars. Mueller is the top producer of Brass rod, and it is likely that the brass used in PRS hardware comes from this plant.
attributes.address: 2199 Lapeer Ave, Port Huron, MI 48060, USA
attributes.title: Mueller Industries - Brass Production

attributes.description: China is the world's top zinc producer. Zinc and Copper and combined to produce brass, a common component of "hardware" (the tuners, and other metal pieces) of a PRS guitar. Other possible zinc mines are located in Australia.
attributes.title: Zinc Mines

attributes.description: It is crucial that the wood in the neck of a guitar be extremely strong, straight grained, sturdy, and tonally full. Hardrock maple is often harvested from Michigan to meet this end on maple-necked guitars. My PRS is unusual, in that, it has a maple neck. Most PRS guitars have rosewood or mahogany necks, which produce a mellower, bassier tone. Maple is characterically bright, and coupled with the single coil P-90s and maple top, my guitar has a unique "quack" to it, that is unusual for PRS guitars.
attributes.title: Hard-Rock Maple

attributes.description: Most flame (figured) maple guitar tops from quality guitar makers come from US harvested wood. It is very likely that the flame maple top of my guitar came from the Pacific Northwest. This is just an approximation, of course, but one could expect the wood in PRS guitars to come from this region. Acer Macrophyllum is used because it is the largest species of Maple tree - reaching a final height of around 50 meters (163 feet) tall.
attributes.title: Maple - Acer Macrophyllum

attributes.description: African Mahogany (Khaya) is native to North Africa. The mahogany in my guitar is most likely African Mahogany. The reason for this being, that it was a production model, and true mahogany (Swietenia, of the Meliacaeae Family) is an endangered wood, and is used primarily in custom (1-of-a-kind) models.
attributes.title: Mahogany

attributes.description: NOVA Chemicals produces Polystyrene, the type of plastic typically used in toys, models, and guitar pickups here. This is likely where the plastic in my guitar's pickups came from - or a similar plant/manufacturer.
attributes.title: NOVA Chemicals Inc. - Beaver Valley Manufacturing Site

attributes.description: TFM's Copper and Cobalt mining facility in the Dem. Rep. of the Congo is one of the world's largest known copper and cobalt resources. It is highly likely that the Cobalt that goes into the Alnico alloys in Seymour Duncan pickups comes from this plant. The DRC is the world's largest cobalt producer, at 22,000 tonnes annually.
attributes.address: Fungurume, Democratic Republic of the Congo
attributes.title: Tenke Fungurume Copper and Cobalt Mining Facility

attributes.description: This is a known hydrometallurgical processing plant belonging to Sherritt Industries, which processes the nickel ore that goes into Seymour Duncan pickups. Canada is the world's second largest Nickel producer after Russia. Nickel is used in creating the Alnico alloy (Aluminum, Nickel, Cobalt) that is famously used in guitar pickups.
attributes.title: Nickel Ore - Hydrometurgical Processing Plant

attributes.description: This town is close to a known Australian Bauxite Mine - bauxite is aluminum ore, which is used in the production of P-90 Soapbar pickups at Seymour Duncan.
attributes.title: Bauxite Mine

attributes.description: This is the New England facility for J. Gibson McIlvain - it is highly likely that any wood that PRS could have bought through McIlvain could have come from this facility.
attributes.title: J. Gibson McIlvain - New England Facility

attributes.description: One of the premier wood suppliers in the country to several major guitar companies. Because of their proximity to PRS guitars, and the evidence that several employees have been affiliated with both companies, it is reasonable to assume that PRS gets much of their lumber from J. Gibson McIlvain.
attributes.address: 10701 Philadelphia Rd, Perry Hall, MD 21128, USA
attributes.title: J. Gibson McIlvain Headquarters

attributes.description: Reitz Hardwoods was founded by a PRS wood buyer, Paul Platts, as a subsidiary company and tonewood provider, either to PRS or other companies.
attributes.title: Reitz Hardwoods - A Subsidiary of PRS Guitars
PRS Guitars Ltd.
attributes.address: 380 Log Canoe Cir, Stevensville, MD 21666, USA
attributes.description: This is the home of PRS Guitars Ltd. Here, all the American models are manufactured from component parts/raw materials. For example, the necks are shaped from raw wood blanks here.

attributes.title: Seymour Duncan Headquarters and Factory
attributes.address: 5427 Hollister Ave, Santa Barbara, CA 93111, USA
attributes.description:
This is where the P-90 pickups for my guitar were assembled from their component parts. The pickups used in the Soapbar model are the vintage models:

http://www.seymourduncan.com/products/electric/specialized/p90/1103463_64_neck/

attributes.title: Retro Guitar, Keene NH
attributes.description:
This is the store where I bought my guitar. 

This is the original ad I saw while surfing the interwebs, that led to the beginning of a beautiful relationship.

http://www.vintageandrare.com/product/Paul-Reed-Smith-Custom-22-Soapbar-1999-Brown-19527
This is the Seymour Duncan Santa Barbara factory, where the pickups in my particular guitar were built.
attributes.title: 5427 Hollister Avenue, Santa Barbara, CA 93111  to 380 Log Canoe Circle, Stevensville, MD 21666
380 Log Canoe Circle, Stevensville, MD 21666  to Retro Guitar, Keene NH

attributes.description: This is the headquarters for a known wood distribution associate of PRS, and a likely candidate for the company that sold PRS the wood that makes up my guitar.
attributes.title: J. Gibson McIlvain Headquarters to PRS Guitars Ltd.
Reitz Hardwoods - A Subsidiary of PRS Guitars to PRS Guitars Ltd.
attributes.description: Reitz Hardwoods was founded by Paul Platts, a senior wood buyer at PRS. It is very likely that the wood for my guitar came through this company, as it deals primarily in the exotic, guitar quality lumber that PRS requires of its higher end models.

attributes.title: J. Gibson McIlvain - New England Facility to J. Gibson McIlvain Headquarters
attributes.description: McIlvain's New England facility. From here, wood is distributed to many of its customers, and wood likely pass through the regional office headquarters in Baltimore before being shipped to PRS Guitars.

attributes.title: Bauxite Mine to Seymour Duncan Headquarters and Factory
Nickel Ore - Hydrometallurgical Processing Plant to Seymour Duncan Headquarters and Factory
Tenke Fungurume Copper and Cobalt Mining Facility to Seymour Duncan Headquarters and Factory
NOVA Chemicals Inc. - Beaver Valley Manufacturing Site to Seymour Duncan Headquarters and Factory
Mahogany to J. Gibson McIlvain - New England Facility
Mahogany to Reitz Hardwoods - A Subsidiary of PRS Guitars
Maple - Acer Macrophyllum to J. Gibson McIlvain - New England Facility
Hard-Rock Maple to J. Gibson McIlvain - New England Facility
Hard-Rock Maple to Reitz Hardwoods - A Subsidiary of PRS Guitars
Nickel Ore - Hydrometurgical Processing Plant to PRS Guitars Ltd.
attributes.description:
PRS uses nickel in their frets, and likely receives the same Canadian nickel that Seymour Duncan uses in their pickups. Small world, eh?

Nickel is also instrumental in the construction of PRS guitar strings, and amplifiers.
Aluminum is used in several of the component parts which PRS uses.
attributes.title: Bauxite Mine to PRS Guitars Ltd.
Mueller Industries - Brass Production to PRS Guitars Ltd.
Zinc Mines to Mueller Industries - Brass Production
Tenke Fungurume Copper and Cobalt Mining Facility to Mueller Industries - Brass Production

attributes.description: Though it is doubtful that PRS buys from NCL directly, the Polyester and Acrylic Urethane finishes they buy wholesale in the US (from any of a number of distributors) were likely manufactured here, or any of hundreds of similar laboratories throughout India, China, and the rest of Asia (US chemical laboratories also exist, don't get the wrong idea).
attributes.title: National Chemical Laboratory to PRS Guitars Ltd.
Retro Guitar, Keene NH to 42 High Street, Perkinsville Vermont
